verses.text: Then Naomi, Ruth’s mother-in-law, said to her, “My daughter, should I not seek rest for you, that it may go well with you?”
verses.comment: Naomi expresses concern for Ruth’s future, seeking stability for her.

verses.text: Now is not Boaz, whose young women you were with, our relative? See, he is winnowing barley tonight at the threshing floor.
verses.comment: Emphasizes Boaz’s kinship and location during the harvest.

verses.text: Wash yourself, anoint yourself, put on your cloak, and go down to the threshing floor. Do not make yourself known to the man until he has finished eating and drinking.
verses.comment: Instructions for approaching Boaz discreetly and respectfully.

verses.text: But when he lies down, observe the place where he lies. Then go and uncover his feet and lie down, and he will tell you what to do.
verses.comment: ‘Uncover his feet’ is kept literal; this is a gesture of humility and seeking protection.

verses.text: And she replied, “All that you say, I will do.”
verses.comment: Shows Ruth’s obedience and trust in Naomi’s plan.

verses.text: So she went down to the threshing floor and did just as her mother-in-law had commanded her.
verses.comment: Ruth acts according to Naomi’s instruction.

verses.text: When Boaz had eaten and drunk, and his heart was cheerful, he went to lie down at the end of the grain pile. Then she came quietly, uncovered his feet, and lay down.
verses.comment: Literal rendering; ‘his heart was cheerful’ is kept from Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: At midnight the man was startled and turned over, and behold, a woman was lying at his feet.
verses.comment: Retains the sense of surprise and context.

verses.text: He said, “Who are you?” And she answered, “I am Ruth, your servant. Spread the corner of your garment over me, for you are a redeemer.”
verses.comment: ‘Spread the corner of your garment’ - idiom preserved; means protection/marriage proposal.

verses.text: And he said, “May you be blessed by the LORD, my daughter. You have shown more kindness now than before, because you have not gone after young men, whether poor or rich.”
verses.comment: Boaz praises Ruth’s loyalty and integrity.

verses.text: And now, my daughter, do not fear. I will do for you all that you ask, for all my people in the city know that you are a worthy woman.
verses.comment: ‘Worthy woman’ corresponds to ‘woman of noble character’.

verses.text: And now, it is true that I am a redeemer. Yet there is a redeemer nearer than I.
verses.comment: Boaz acknowledges legal requirements for redemption.

verses.text: Stay here tonight, and in the morning, if he will redeem you, good; let him do it. But if he is not willing to redeem you, then as the LORD lives, I will redeem you. Lie down until the morning.
verses.comment: ‘As the LORD lives’ is a solemn oath.

verses.text: So she lay at his feet until morning, but got up before anyone could recognize another. For he said, “Let it not be known that the woman came to the threshing floor.”
verses.comment: Preserves the sense of discretion and protection of Ruth’s reputation.

verses.text: And he said, “Bring the cloak you are wearing and hold it out.” So she held it, and he measured out six measures of barley and put it on her. Then she went into the city.
verses.comment: ‘Six measures’ kept as literal. Some translations specify ephahs, but Hebrew is ambiguous.

verses.text: When she came to her mother-in-law, she said, “How did it go, my daughter?” Then she told her all that the man had done for her.
verses.comment: Hebrew literally: ‘Who are you, my daughter?’ but context shows inquiry about outcome.

verses.text: She said, “He gave me these six measures of barley, for he said to me, ‘Do not go back to your mother-in-law empty-handed.’”
verses.comment: ‘Empty-handed’ echoes Naomi’s own words about her return.

verses.text: And she said, “Wait, my daughter, until you know how the matter turns out. For the man will not rest but will settle the matter today.”
verses.comment: Naomi reassures Ruth that Boaz will act quickly.
